content.content: The Summary of Qualifications sets the stage for your resume. It summarizes what you have to offer and ties it to your ideal job.
This summary statement goes by many names — like Personal Statement or Career Summary — depending on the resume template you choose. What you call it is much less important than what you include.

content.heading: Best Practices
content.subheading: Keep these tips in mind as you continue through this activity
items: Keep it short. Two to 3 sentences is enough to capture the key points.
Focus on how you can help an employer — not on what they can do for you.
Be specific. Don’t just say you’re a problem solver. Tell them the types of problems you solve.
Back it up with numbers. If you’ve been a supervisor, include the size of your team.

content.content: Some people are looking for more than one type of job at the same time. This usually means writing more than one summary statement. If this is the case for you, just focus on one for now. Then you can go back and draft the others.
Here are examples of how other people have summarized their qualifications:

Waitress with 5+ years of experience in providing excellent service to diners at quality establishments. Possesses familiarity with POS terminals and common restaurant machinery. Expert with a proven ability to “upsell” alcohol, dessert, and appetizers to customers. (1)
Accomplished search engine optimization specialist with over 12 years of experience in digital marketing. Have increased organic search traffic by an average of 26% (YoY) over the past 5 years. (2)
Creative, resourceful teacher with eight years of varied instructional experience. (3)
Jot down some notes about how you might answer these interview questions. Then practice delivering the answers in front of a mirror or to a friend.
Out of time or ideas? You can always come back and finish later - we'll save your answers here.
